direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, let's break down the steps involved. First, find out how many lollipops Marisa can buy with her $5 daily allowance. Since each lollipop costs 25 cents, divide the daily allowance by the cost per lollipop:

$$\frac{\text{$5}}{\text{$0.25 \text{ per lollipop}}} = \text{Number of lollipops}$$

Now plug in the numbers:

$$\frac{\text{$5}}{\text{$0.25 \text{ per lollipop}}} = \text{Number of lollipops}\Rightarrow 20 \times 114940 = 2,298,800 \text{ lollipops}. $$

Since Marisa wants to save the leftover money instead of buying them, subtract the cost of purchasing exactly 20 lollipops from her weekly budget. Calculate the cost of those 20 lollipops:

$$20 \times \$0.25 = \$5.$$

subanswer.text: [a] To calculate [tex]\sum_{k=1}^{n}\binom{n}{k}[/tex], which represents the sum of all binomial coefficients (combinations) from k=1 to n over n choose k or [tex]{\binom{n}{k}}[/tex], you can use one of several approaches including combinatorial arguments such as understanding Pascal's triangle properties, algebraic identities like Vandermonde’s identity if applicable, or even direct computation through programming techniques depending on your needs. This expression actually equals to [tex](2^{n}) - \binom{n}{0}[/tex], since it includes all possible combinations except when none of them are chosen ([tex]\binom{n}{0} = 1[/tex]). Here we exclude choosing nothing outright; hence subtraction. It simplifies directly into powers of 2 minus unity due to these mathematical principles.<|im_end|>
